body:
i added 'uid' to the array on line 886 of user_ldap/lib/access.php, tried logging in, and it worked perfectly.

so, i'd definitely suggest adding a field on the admin page for this. i only use the uid attribute because it's required by certain object classes. my real uuid field is on my custom object class i built for our institution. so no one else would ever use it, and it would be pointless to hard code it into owncloud.

i'm leaving this open since it seems like a bug to me. i'll let you close the issue if you want to.
@blizzz

uid is not necessarily unique, this should not be looked for when determining a unique identifier (uuid). ldap servers have an attribute for each object which contains the uuid, usually it is one of those included. do you know which one is used by novell edirectory?
after some more googleing it might be "guid". can you add this instead and truncate the tables oc_ldap_user_mapping and oc_ldap_group_mapping (not on working production servers)?

i need to find out how to convert the guid's value then. 

the uuid id is used to identify a user.

may i ask what your reasoning for using operational attributes like guid for the uuid is? if there's a prior issue on the subject, that would be great.

i haven't tested this, but i would imagine it likely that deleting an entry, then recreating it would change the guid. maybe even moving the dn. as an admin, i'd much rather use whatever attribute i set as the uuid for my users, than an operational attribute like guid. 'course, maybe i'm doing something wrong...

it is used to make sure that mallory does not get alices or bobs data. and/or to avoid that alice or bob cannot access their data. the reason is that other attributes may be not unique or are likely to change. we used dn before and it was by far not good enough.

it is true however that when you delete a ldap user and want to recreate it you also must make sure that the uuid match. or you manually change the value of the column directory_uuid in the database table oc_ldap_user_mapping if it happens only once in a while.
p.s.: if someone wonders about alice and bob https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/alice_and_bob

you're right, using the uuid will help ensure mallory does not get alices or bobs data.

my problem is that the ldap directory is not the authoritative source for our users. thus, i have a custom ldap attribute that holds the id from the database that is the authoritative source. in the event of a move from edirectory to openldap, that custom attribute would transfer, i have no idea if the guid would even be compatible with openldap. which would mean remapping owncloud users to their openldap entries could get messy.

basically, i can guarantee that my custom attribute is unique within my organization, and i can use it when moving between different systems. i can't be sure i could do that with the guid. and trying to do so would incur a lot of work that isn't needed when i already have my custom attribute.

could you add an override for systems administrators like me? maybe just variable in config.php?

> in the event of a move from edirectory to openldap, that custom attribute would transfer, i have no idea if the guid would even be compatible with openldap.

openldap would need the exact string-representation of the guid. i'd assume it should work, but you could also set up a migration script that updates the uuid.

> basically, i can guarantee that my custom attribute is unique within my organization

i believe you, but we require an approach that ideally works everywhere, not for every single setup.

> i can use it when moving between different systems.

how often do you do this? we could think about a migration tool for oc 6.

> could you add an override for systems administrators like me? maybe just variable in config.php? 

for owncloud 5 it is too late, we are in bugfixing-only mode. and it must be integrated into ldap settings, because it is server-configuration dependent and you can have more of them now.

compatibility with novell's guid of course can be included.

> openldap would need the exact string-representation of the guid. i'd assume it should work, but you could also set up a migration script that updates the uuid.

true, but i'd like to avoid writing scripts like that whenever possible. especially when it comes to something like controlling access to users files.


> i believe you, but we require an approach that ideally works everywhere, not for every single setup.

hence an override that most will never use, just the few who are in similar situations as i am. 


> how often do you do this? we could think about a migration tool for oc 6.

hopefully not often. but identity related systems are in rather major flux at my workplace. i'm currently moving off an old edirectory that's got a lot of old entries in it into a new one with a new structure. and this new one could easily be merged into a different directory a little ways down the road. maybe into something that isn't edirectory... so i'm very leery of every users guid staying the same. and thus very leery of using it to control access to files in owncloud if we decide to use owncloud. (which i really really want to do.)

i'd much rather connect the files to an organization wide uid, than to an application specific uuid.

plus, i'd love to get away from edirectory some time in the future... sadly that isn't possible for me now.... 

since you're in bug fix only mode, i'll likely just have to hack core. it'll be easy enough to add my attribute to that array of uuid attributes. not an ideal fix, but that's life. unless i could write a plugin to add the override i want... would that be possible?

i do agree adding compatibility with edirectory's guid is a good idea if it's possible. edirectory is sadly very popular.

> since you're in bug fix only mode, i'll likely just have to hack core. it'll be easy enough to add my attribute to that  array of uuid attributes. not an ideal fix, but that's life. unless i could write a plugin to add the override i want...  would that be possible?

easiest would be to patch it for now.
you might be able to write an app, subclass access.php and implement your adjusted own method.

could you do me a favor and check whether following works:

1. add 'guid' to the uuid attributes to check and truncate the database tables as done here https://github.com/owncloud/core/issues/1968#issuecomment-14226063

2. change this line to https://github.com/owncloud/core/blob/master/apps/user_ldap/lib/access.php#l87
```
} elseif(strtolower($attr) == 'objectguid' || strtolower($attr) == 'guid') {
```

3. check whether it works as expected
it works. i was able to authenticate against edirectory.
could you clarify how owncloud knows who owns what file? i was just looking at a few of the tables in the database, and i'm not sure how the user is connected to the files.
hrmm... in the user list the login name is displaying as the string representation of the guid. when i'm actually logging in with my cn.

you define how you login by login filter. whether it is username, email adress, both, something different, this is up to you. 

owncloud recognizes ldap users using their uuid. they are mapped to the internal username (as of oc 5 generated from the uuid, too, theoretically can be different). with the internal username all the user data are referenced. by default, the users "home" folder has also the same name as the internal username (= uuid). you can specifiy another attribute which values is being used for this (user home folder naming rule in advanced tab).

so ldap users have their internal username set as their entries uuid. the files are mapped to the internal username. 

the /settings/users login name column would really be the internal username. 

thanks for the help. i think that pretty much covers all my questions.
welcome!
